posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

A big problem you have to understand is how much racism played in geopolitics back then

Japan, while seen as a rising power. Was still seen as inferior to the white race (them defeating Russia was a major shock simply because nobody believed a non White country could beat a white one in a war at that point)

In the treaty of Versailles, Japan wanted a racial equality clause included. The idea being that all League of Nations members would pledge to uphold racial equality.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Racial_Equality_Proposal

USA and British empire veto’d it for obvious reasons.

So japan already felt it was treated poorly for unjustified reasons. One way to gain the respect they felt they deserved was expansion and militarism. The defeat of Russia and attacking China with the other members of the eight nation alliance were the two biggest events that propelled japan from just another backwards Asian country to one seen as more civilised and closer to a western country. So naturally it makes sense they’d think doing more of this was the best way to continually get more respect and general geopolitical power.

Also, much like Germany. Japan was engaging in a naval arms race for a while. Against both Britain and America, who both felt entitled to Pacific domination.

So when the naval arms limitations treaty was pushed for by the League of Nations. Japan saw it as just a way to try and bully them into submission, and renounced the treaty and later left the league entirely

20-10 is pretty common. Not so common for kings though because you would need to wait some years to conceive, which is why you don't hear about it so often. For the ancients, a man in his 20s and a 10 year old girl who has just reached puberty are in the same age range of "young person". They didn't have any arbitrary 16 or 18 line that decided whether a person is an adult or not, if they did, they put it at around 40 or 50 years of age. And they definitely did not consider so-called "adulthood" as a prerequisite for marriage

There were many reasons why Irish troops were enthusiastic to fight for US armies-whether Union or Confederate, but two of the main ones are:
>Citizenship/Respect
Irish people were not respected or well treated in the US, unsurprisingly; they arrived in droves as often monolingual impoverished and unskilled tenant farm labourers, with little to offer to urban centres on the East Coast. Military service was one fairly reliable path to "integration" or "acceptance" as Americans. Irish leaders in the Army were capitalised on by the US to take advantage of the Irish manpower pool, as was the case with Michael Corcoran and the 69th.
>Republican Tricks
Irish Revolutionary leaders encouraged their followers to enlist to gain military experience to be later used against Britain, as we saw in the Fenian Raids.

The US Civil War wasn't really about religion, and by this stage Irish Nationalism and Nationhood had an almost century old tradition of religious unity (United Irishmen, etc). So there wasn't too many reasons not to fight, in all honesty.

>>14401747
Pope Benedict XVI (German: Benedikt XVI.; born Joseph Aloisius Ratzinger, German; 16 April 1927 - 31 December 2022) was a prelate of the Catholic Church who served as the head of the Church and the sovereign of the Vatican City State from 19 April 2005 until his resignation on 28 February 2013. Benedict's election as pope occurred in the 2005 papal conclave that followed the death of Pope John Paul II. Benedict chose to be known by the title "pope emeritus" upon his resignation. Ordained as a priest in 1951 in his native Bavaria, Ratzinger embarked on an academic career and established himself as a highly regarded theologian by the late 1950s. He was appointed a full professor in 1958 at the age of 31. After a long career as a professor of theology at several German universities, he was appointed Archbishop of Munich and Freising and created a cardinal by Pope Paul VI in 1977, an unusual promotion for someone with little pastoral experience. In 1981, he was appointed Prefect of the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith, one of the most important dicasteries of the Roman Curia. From 2002 until his election as pope, he was also Dean of the College of Cardinals. Prior to becoming pope, he was "a major figure on the Vatican stage for a quarter of a century"; he had an influence "second to none when it came to setting church priorities and directions" as one of John Paul II's closest confidants. He lived in Rome from 1981 until his death in 2022. His prolific writings generally defend traditional Catholic doctrine and values. He was originally a liberal theologian, but adopted conservative views after 1968. During his papacy, Benedict XVI advocated a return to fundamental Christian values to counter the increased secularisation of many Western countries.

>>14404214
They are distinguished by virtue of the "real" chair preceding the chair in my imagination in terms of the temporal sequence of phenomena. The idea or mental image of a chair that I can recall is an echo of a past perception, hence the logical and actual priority of perception over cognition. The intellect is thus active only when experience is supplied to it, either through perception or memory (i.e. experience recalled). This necessarily proves the existence of an external reality independent of my mental states, otherwise I wouldn't have anything to think about. I am not the cause of my own perceptions.


Materialism, like idealism, goes too far in what it can reasonably prove. Even the starting premise of 'matter's' basic definition (i.e. that which takes up space or possesses 'extension') has been repeatedly revised in order to keep the theory relevant; most contemporary 'materialists' are actually substance metaphysicians who necessarily stretch the meaning of 'matter' so as to be so broad that it no longer resembles any historic Materialist position. Even a cursory understanding of contemporary physics renders all forms of materialism into fossilized relics of an earlier age that possessed, by comparison, a quaint and overly simplistic view of ontology.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
They did have writing. Why they chose knots, Quipu, over marks on clay or wood I do not know, but they lived in a very unique environment as far as pre-industrial civilizations go where messengers ran long distances in the mountains. Perhaps string was easier to carry and more resilient to damage.

Their Empire stretched 2500 miles along the Andes approximately the length of the Roman Empire east to west, except on foot in rough terrain. This limited trade, meaning trade could only be carried out on a large scale by the state, although some of their vassals had currency and merchants, the Inca state apparently monopolized trade. They implemented a planned economy, unlike the Soviet Union which suffered from constant shortages, it was based on surpluses, goods were first stockpiled in storehouses, Qullqa, where agents would record the amount of goods using their Quipu. The state would then decide where to send these goods and how they were to be used.

It was not utopian communism as some claim, it existed to serve the aristocracy which lived in opulence with multitudes of servants and concubines and conducted imperialist wars of conquest. The so called Ayni principle of altruism and benevolence was more an obligation for the lower classes to serve and give up their goods resembling serfdom. It was state enforced cuckoldry, but an interesting system nonetheless.

Today only a few families living on the shores of the city of Puno identify themselves as such, but it used to be a larger group around the lake, and in older times perhaps as far as the vicinity of Cusco.

The Urubamba valley (adjacent to Cusco's valley but about a 1000 meters lower, allows a warmer climate that consequently enabled it to become the powerhouse of early Inca agriculture), or Urupampa may very well imply an ancestralism of the Uro associated with with a hypothesis that they originated in the high jungle who came to settle in the heart of the Altiplano, being the former perhaps one of the primordial branches.

>>14404893
Survivor bias and an understanding of what Tokugawa-era castles were. During the Sengoku Jidai, the Japanese had thousands of forts/castles but they were mostly wooden palisades and earthworks. None survived. I imagine they look just as shitty and varied as Europeans (the Euros have examples of shitty stone watchtowers and elaborate 1600s onward chateaus).

After the Tokugawa Shogunate took over, they established a 1-castle per domain policy for non-Tokugawa daiymo. The Japanese dismantled excess castles and this reduced the number of extant castles from thousands to ~300, effectively 1 per domain. Because each Daiymo was allowed only one castle, they almost always built their castles near their largest urban center and could invest lavishly into it like a pet project. They were basically just mansions, but also served as government offices. So practicality gave way to just making it look fucking nice and wealthy. The Daiymo lived there other every year because of sankin kōtai. And when he wasn't there, his family was living there. So it was important to make castles feel comfortable as fuck, especially if you're hosting or entertaining vassals, overlords, or esteemed guests. Weakness or lack of providing extreme hospitality could mean lost of power and prestige, loss of court rank, confiscation of lands, or harakiri in the most extreme cases.

The countryside were ruled over by samurai, tax collectors and bureaucrats on behalf of the daiymo, who lived in manse/manor houses - basically just a really nice country houses. Again, they'd just build them for comfort and offices, not actual military installations.

posts.com:
Thoughts on Anglicans?

They believe their worship is a continuation of the Roman Catholic Mass, but their understanding of the sacraments is closer to the Reformed. They also say there are only two sacraments: Baptism and Communion. The five lesser rites of the Church are: confirmation, absolution, marriage, holy orders, and anointing of the sick. Anglicans deny the doctrine of transubstantiation, and practice infant baptism.

Anglicans generally accept the definition of Sola Fide as found in Lutheranism and Reformed Protestantism, but reject Sola Scriptura in favor of Prima Scriptura as the writings of the Church Fathers, the Ecumenical Councils, and the Creeds still play an important role in Anglican theology. Anglicans also accept the 66 book Protestant canon of the Holy Bible as scripture but continue to use the 7 books of the deuterocanon as secondary texts, below that of scripture, but still useful for devotional activity.

Anglicans do invoke saints to pray for them, but to a lesser degree than Catholic and Orthodox Christians. Mary is considered the greatest creature of God among Anglicans, the Mother of God, and is venerated highly, considered by most to be a perpetual virgin and without sin, but her immaculate conception and assumption are generally rejected as Papist elaborations.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
As such, Anglicans reject many other Roman Catholic dogmas like purgatory and papal supremacy, but what really distinguishes them from most other Protestants is their continued acceptance of the ministerial priesthood, apostolic succession among bishops, and an episcopal polity. Like Eastern Orthodox, caesaropapism has historically been part of Anglicanism. The Archbishop of Canterbury is first among equals in Anglicanism.

Like in Catholicism, art and statues continue to play a central role in Anglican worship, but to a slightly lesser degree than in Catholicism. So it is not uncommon to come across icons or three dimensional crucifixes in Anglican churches, like in a Catholic church.

Of course like the vast majority of Christians, Anglicans profess the orthodox definition of the Holy Trinity and incarnation of Jesus. But on certain social issues, like the ordination of women, Anglicans do ordain them. Anglicanism is a heavily liturgical tradition just like Catholicism and follows a very similar liturgical calender to seasons like Lent and Advent are celebrated.

> Another perceived problem with Aristotle’s science was that it was based on a confidence in the unaided powers of human reason and the senses. Aristotle had taken the sanguine view that our cognitive and sensory powers were aligned with nature and would unproblematically yield a relatively accurate picture of the world and its workings. Aristotelian science was accordingly based on commonsense observations of nature. This approach gave rise to a number of familiar, but erroneous, Aristotelian doctrines: a heavy object (the stone) will always fall more quickly than the light one (the feather); terrestrial objects move in straight lines and will eventually come to rest; celestial objects move perpetually in circular paths.

> For Protestant critics, the human fall from perfection – crucially, a fall that damaged both human moral capacities and sensory and cognitive abilities – fatally compromised Aristotelian scholasticism. Medieval Christian thinkers had acknowledged the Fall, but Luther and John Calvin contended that they had failed to take full cognisance of its implications for the sciences. He went on to express skepticism about the scientific doctrines of ‘the heathen master’ Aristotle, who ‘taught and still teaches … that a stone is heavy, that a feather is light, that water is wet, and fire is dry’. Medieval Scholastic philosophers and university masters of arts, according to Luther, had accepted the false Aristotelian premise that ‘natural light or intellect and heathen philosophy are also safe means of discovering truth’.

> This led to Bacon’s Novum Organum (1621) which was an influential manifesto for a new, non-Aristotelian science.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1. Perpetual Virginity -- the statements regarding Jesus having brothers can be read either way linguistically, there is typology which could apply to Mary, Eze. 44:2, and there is intertexual comparison of Mary with the ark of the covenant in Luke. What we need is a reason to read these things in this way. First we should note what perpetual virginity actually is, which is that Mary was a virgin before, during, and after birth. The "during" means that her virginity remained physically intact as Christ's birth was of a miraculous nature. If this did not occur, then it means that Christ damaged his own mother's physical virginity, which is too impious to consider. This must be avoided, and thus we must at least affirm Mary's virginity during birth. This would fit the typology of Eze. 44:2, and thus also affirm her virginity after birth.

2. Immaculate Conception -- this teaches that Mary was saved by a retroactive application of Christ's saving work: at the moment of her conception she was saved by Christ and preserved from original sin, and cooperated with God's will in committing no personal sins, so that original sin would not pass to Christ. God prepared her as a holy vessel, for if Mary is stained with sin, then that means that God dwelt bodily in a body that was sinful, as his body was within Mary's body, and he took his flesh from Mary's flesh. How can God dwell within a sinful body? Further we know that God is a consuming fire, Heb. 12:29, but this fire burned in Mary's womb and she was not burned -- she is a typological fulfillment of the burning bush -- and she was not consumed because she bore no sin. One should also consider the special love that God has for Mary, for example the icon I have posted which shows God's special relationship to her. Imagine a being which God loves with the special love that a child gives to his mother, and this being raising up God himself as a child. The doctrine is functionally necessary.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14399739
(cont.)

3. Bodily Assumption -- as Mary was conceived without the stain of original sin, it means that she, like Eve, was not subject to natural death, and would need to be assumed bodily into heaven at the end of the time God has allotted for her on Earth. This is a direct consequence of the former doctrine.

He was an excellent organizer, and had a genius for logistics. The problem was that he also fancied himself a great field general.

Field generals need to possess a few traits, among others:
>Ruthlessness toward the enemy and their own troops
You need to be willing to do whatever it takes to win the war, and sometimes that means giving orders you know will result in casualties on your own side. McClellan was a little too attached to his troops for his own good, while Grant, despite not being the drunken butcher portrayed in Lost Cause media, was capable of giving those orders and living with that weight on his soul.

>Decisive action
McClellan lacked the willingness to commit to an action and proceed from there. He was always coming up with ridiculously complex schemes when sometimes the best plan is to walk up to the other guy and shoot him in the face. Worse was that he just would hold off from engaging for fear of large enemy numbers or whatever the hell reason he could come up with.

McClellan would have made an excellent chief of staff in the Eisenhower sense, but he was no field general. The difference however, is that Eisenhower knew he was no great field general and was willing and able to put the right people in those positions. McClellan wanted to be the next Napoleon, a fancy made sillier by the fact that the Civil War marks the end of Napoleonic warfare and the dawn of industrial warfare proper.

>>14392118
>For example, the US had vastly superior systems of supply for most of its wars against gorillas
To add to the guy who said wars were won mostly by will and logistics we need to add another important variable, which is strategy. If one has declared war against something like "terror," or if one has poorly defined or impossible goals, then they have severely burdened their fighting force.

Consequently, the reason why a weaker side might still fight a war is because their war goals could be completely different, time might be on their side due to the differing strategies involved. They might just have to hold their ground and be on the defensive to win, while the other side has to extend into dangerous territory and expose themselves more to the elements of attrition. So even if one has excellent logistics to help avoid an all-out catastrophe, and even if one has a far greater force than the other side, one can still lose to attrition anyway. Things like winter weather and disease can still ravage a force, regardless of supply lines. We saw this for instance in the Crimean war, which saw massive attrition to disease, the horrendous result of which led to much more focus by the Europeans on medical attention being available on future battlefields. The fact that newspapers at the time were beginning to be able to report on battlefield conditions to the rest of the world relatively quickly, probably also spurred this development.

So, applying this to the example of Vietnam, we can see that the gorillas just had to outlast an opponent who was strategically unwilling to escalate the conflict beyond a certain point. This could be seen not as a logistical failure as much as a strategic one, because the goal of winning without escalating beyond a certain point proved impossible, therefore turning the theater into an endless meat grinder. And even if they had battlefield success to report on, that wouldn't change this problem.

''I'm a damned sight smarter than Grant; I know more about organization, supply and administration and about everything else than he does; but I'll tell you where he beats me and where he beats the world. He don't care a damn for what the enemy does out of his sight but it scares me like hell.''

posts.com: Neoteny in humans is the retention of juvenile traits well into adulthood. This trend is greatly amplified in humans especially when compared to non-human primates. Adult humans more closely resemble the infants of gorillas and chimpanzees than the adults of those animals. Neotenic features of the head include the globular skull; thinness of skull bones; the reduction of the brow ridge; the large brain; the flattened and broadened face; the hairless face; hair on (top of) the head; larger eyes; ear shape; small nose; small teeth; and the small maxilla (upper jaw) and mandible (lower jaw).

posts.com: To elaborate on what >>14398872 said, it was a different time. The idea was that you could make perfect policy using purely technical means of establishing it ie science. While this sounds great and fully workable on paper, in real life it completely failed because none of the technocrats involved bothered to ask why would Vietnamese trust Americans in the first place when their government was run by a religious minority, a bully, and had such a backwards unworkable rice economy. The Tet Offensive both proved and disproved this thinking - the TO was successfully repelled, but it totally broke morale. No amount of numbers and math can argue with Walter Cronkite going on TV and announcing that the war is unwinnable. Weary troops don't care about how many people they've killed or how many miles of roads were built, it's erased the next day either by the enemy or by themselves (see Nixon's Operation Menu as an example of this). Then the OPEC Embargo happened for purely religious reasons, and the US economy choked because economists didn't account for crazy religious people wielding their power aggressively.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: In a modern context, it is very similar to Bush in Iraq. The attempts at nationbuilding failed spectacularly by 2005 necessitating the Surge in 2006-7 in time for the mortgage meltdown. Despite using the latest technology to build Iraq a stock market, a telecom network, Internet, and modern biometric IDs it all collapsed in 2011 when ISIS rose. Obama likewise failed to figure out the entire Arab Spring - his technocrats (specifically Secretary of State Hilary Clinton) had an entire menu and liberalization roadmap for the entire region, just as a means to contain Iran. It failed with the American Ambassador to Libya being killed and ISIS outright murdering all opposing factions using weapons given to them by the CIA. Then, after murdering their CIA contacts, became the primary force in the region until the US could agree to not bomb Assad allowing the Russians in. Total meltdown of US policy that America still hasn't recovered from.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
So, back to Ford. Ford was by then a large mature company helping dismantle America's defunct, outdated and unwanted railroad network. Ford, and the rest of the auto industry, were building the World Of Tomorrow they promised in 1933. With the core Interstate network built out, cars were faster than ever and millions of Americans were liberated economically as they could live and work wherever they wanted. Gas was nickles to the gallon and some of the fastest road cars ever built would soon be released to the public. With such massive domestic success, it was only natural to pave the entire planet in freeways. It's certainly why American companies like Esso and Union Carbide were in Vietnam - they wanted their oil, their minerals, and their labor to produce car parts in an increasingly globalized market just as they did with Brazil vis-a-vis rubber tires thirty years prior. New plastics meant a whole new world of manufacturing was plausible, requiring new machines. Chief amongst these were the Bradley IFV/M113 (which is now being replaced with the OMFV/M1284 due to the Ukraine War) and the M-16, which came to symbolize the war's failures as early models were prone to cracking and breaking under stress.

I mention this because the other side of the war was the nationbuilding in the locomotives, trucks, power plants and other miscellany we sent to Vietnam as we also sent to Korea, Japan and West Germany. It was around ~1960 where American companies bothered to keep records of this stuff, and cameras had become cheap enough where records of such things could exist. And this was also how the war came home through television and newspapers, similar to the civil rights debate. This latter part matters because the people in charge could not account for the public's response to such visceral, real images of war, and this gradually annhilated the Nixon adminsitration when he failed to get us out as he promised. Which relates to the growing domestic peace movement.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I've posted a lot but I just want to point out: if you really want insight on this topic then read about the evolution of counterculture. Today it's so trite - you're on a counterculture website and it's so easy to access. But not back then, such groups were much smaller and had to meet physically IRL or distribute newsletters. This was most often done at colleges, much to the frustration of their administrations, which led to the student movements for civil rights then antiwar. The former had the bus burnings and the subsequent civil rights act, the latter had the kent state shooting by national guardsmen. There's a clear line here from about 1945 to 1975, and JFK's logic like Nixon's was firmly rooted in the 1950s. Nixon only differed in that he was willing to recognize Taiwan and not invade Cuba, which earned him many enemies within the CIA causing his paranoia. Saturn/Cronus was a pre-Indoeuropean deity, associated with fertility. He was likely the main god of the pre-Hellenic popuolation of Greece. >The present study was undertaken to investigate mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) control region sequences of Hazaras from Pakistan, so as to generate mtDNA reference database for forensic casework in Pakistan and to analyze phylogenetic relationship of this particular ethnic group with geographically proximal populations. Complete mtDNA control region (nt 16024-576) sequences were generated through Sanger Sequencing for 319 Hazara individuals from Quetta, Baluchistan. The population sample set showed a total of 189 distinct haplotypes, belonging mainly to West Eurasian (51.72%), East & Southeast Asian (29.78%) and South Asian (18.50%) haplogroups. Compared with other populations from Pakistan, the Hazara population had a relatively high haplotype diversity (0.9945) and a lower random match probability (0.0085). The dataset has been incorporated into EMPOP database under accession number EMP00680. The data herein comprises the largest, and likely most thoroughly examined, control region mtDNA dataset from Hazaras of Pakistan.

>Yishiha (Chinese: 亦失哈; Wade–Giles: Ishiha/I-shih-ha; also Išiqa or Isiha[1] Jurchen: Yishiha.svg i ʃï xa[2]) (fl. 1409–1451) was a Jurchen eunuch in the service of the Ming dynasty emperors who carried out several expeditions down the Songhua and Amur Rivers during the period of Ming rule of Manchuria,[1][3] and is credited with the construction of the only two Ming dynasty Buddhist temples ever built on the territory of present-day Russia.[4]

Is there truth? I think there probably is because I believe there's an objective universe, based on my observations. I could be wrong though. Due to the problem of induction, I reckon we can't be truly certain of anything. We just have to make our best guesses at knowledge.

>but what about a priori knowledge?
"All bachelors are unmarried men"... you might say that's a priori true, and as such is not subject to the problem of induction. But what if, in 100 years' time, the meaning of the word "bachelor" has changed? What if ends up including women too? (Like the word "actor" is now used for women as well.) So really I think all knowledge is empirical, including the definition of the word "bachelor".

Also think about "2 + 2 = 4". That won't be true anymore if the meaning of "4" changes. But also, I would argue that "2 + 2 = 4" expresses an observation about the universe. It could be that adding two pairs of things caused a fifth thing to pop into existence. Then "2 + 2 = 5" would be true. But that isn't the case. So we're expressing empirical knowledge when we say "2 + 2 = 4".

Atheism and religions are different classes of objects. Religions are generally complete worldviews that come as a package deal, whereas atheism is merely one component of a worldview, which appears in many different package-deal worldviews (e.g. Communism, Objectivism, most schools of Buddhism depending on how you define 'god') some of which may be religions. >>14404492
if you want to siege down a fort your army needs to be much bigger than the garrison because otherwise the garrison will easily wear down the attackers. An army wages war on it's stomach and the attacking army is going to consume many times more food(which needs to be safely hauled to the besieging army across enemy territory) than the garrison. Since sieges often last months you need a huge amount of resources to siege. Not to mention, forts slow down enemy armies which allows for reinforcements to come and attack the army together with the garrison.
If you choose to instead completely ignore the fort and just go around it, you won't be able to supply your army because the garrison will simply raid your supply chain and in general simply be a massive weak point
